Posts.Content: Feb 17, 2013 09:09PM swimmom3 wrote: Hi Anna: I started TDM-1 through expanded access at Johns Hopkins on January 9th.  I've had 2 infusions so far and have a third one on Wednesday.  No scans yet, but will have them soon to check how my two spinal mets are reacting.  I know everyone reacts differently to treatments, but I have to say that this has been a very easy treatment for me.  I did get the expected drop in platelets after infusion which for me could be a problem since my platelets are naturally low, however they recovered before my next infusion.  There was some slight elevation in my liver enzymes, but they stayed in the normal range.  Physically the day after my first infusion I woke up feeling a little queasy.  It was nothing that required anti-nausea meds.  To me it just felt like I ate something that didn't agree with me.  It was not enough of an issue though to keep me home from work.  After four days, the queasiness was gone.  I was also a little tired at night when I came home from work, but I just went to bed early and I felt fine the next day.  With my second treatment, the queasiness lasted only two days and I had only slight fatigue. I hope that you have a similar response and that TDM-1 keeps us stable or better yet NED for a long time to come--Cathy
Posts.Title: Anyone on T-DM1? violinfingers Pbjarrett

Posts.Content: Apr 1, 2013 11:18PM swimmom3 wrote: Hi spamgirl.  I've had 4 infusions so far and fatigue that only lasts about 3 days total.  I get treatments on a Wednesday and go home and relax and I still make it to work the next day.  I just come home and relax on Thursday and Friday night and by Saturday it's pretty much gone.  Didn't have real nausea, just felt queasy, like I wasn't very hungry for a few days and then that passed in 3 days too.  I notice that the TDM-1 does get my eczema going a bit and I will get a few patches on my arms and chest for about a week which clear right up with cortisone.  I do get the platelet drop and elevated liver enzymes too, but nothing out of range so far.  I think that risk rises the longer you are on the drug.  It is not affecting my hair (I have a short pixie cut) but it does seem slightly thinner, but I think I just notice it because since it grew back, I'm all about my hair lol.  Good luck with your first infusion.  Cathy
Posts.Title: Anyone on T-DM1? violinfingers Pbjarrett

Posts.Content: Apr 4, 2013 02:54AM swimmom3 wrote: Hi Spamgirl.  Sorry you are so tired today.  These drugs hit everyone differently and we all have our unique experiences.  I had my 5th treatment this afternoon.  I went after work and was home by 545pm.  I'll be in bed in a half hour, not so much because of the TDM-1 but because I had a busy day at work (I'm a teacher's aide at a school for special needs children--physically demanding, but I enjoy every minute because the kids truly make me forget about cancer so I can focus on them).  I know I will be tired and queasy in the morning if it's like my other treatments, but I will drag my butt out of bed and bring a pepsi to sip on all day and I will rest when I get home. This is completely different from my chemo coma that I experienced on TCH last year.  I hope you feel better soon and just rest up and pamper yourself--you deserve it.  Good luck with your treatment, Cathy
Posts.Title: Anyone on T-DM1? violinfingers Pbjarrett

Posts.Content: Apr 11, 2013 04:04AM swimmom3 wrote: Hi Spamgirl.  My spinal mets were much less painful after 2 treatments and now I've had 5 and hardly feel them unless I sit for too long on a hard bench or bleachers (attending son's swim meets) or if I've had a very busy day at work (teacher's aide--very physical).  It used to be unbearable to lay flat on my back --it would immediately wake me out of a deep sleep and now I can sleep in almost any position without pain.  I'm waiting to get with my oncologist next week about something that showed up in my liver on a recent CT scan.  I'm praying it's just related to my fatty liver disease because I would love to continue on this drug for a long time.  I hope it works well for you and that your pain goes away quickly.--Cathy
Posts.Title: Anyone on T-DM1? violinfingers Pbjarrett

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2013 07:52PM swimmom3 wrote: I know I was sore for about a week or two after placement, but I now no longer even know I have a port until I go for treatment or need blood drawn.  I love it and even though it's getting "cranky" about giving a good blood return, I still would rather have a port than get stuck in my arm every few weeks.  To help with blood return, I've been given high dose heparin and even TPA twice to keep it working well.  If the crankiness continues, I am considering having it replaced because now that I'm stage iv, I know I'll be on treatment for life.  Might as well be comfortable. Good luck with your port and treatments.
Posts.Title: Port Placement Z28Femme justjudie
How Many Are We? DivineMrsM kt1966

Posts.Content: Aug 15, 2013 08:09PM swimmom3 wrote: Hi Goldengirl, I am so sorry about your sister's diagnosis, but you came to the right place to get information and support.  I started Kadcyla in Jan 2013 after a Nov bone mets diagnosis.  I began this drug through expanded access, while it was still in a trial. While everyone's experience is different, I have to say that my side effects have been mild, especially when I compare it to my TCH chemo back in September 2011.  Usually on the night of the infusion I feel a bit tired and not very hungry.  This general "yucky" feeling lasts about 3 days and then I am on the upswing.  Again, I have mild to moderate fatigue for about 3-4 days and low appetite.  It does lower my platelets and slightly elevate my liver enzymes, but not enough to cancel treatments.  I am still able to work (very physical job as teacher's aide of special needs students) and take care of my family.  I just have to make sure I rest when I'm tired so I try to focus on one thing a day after work (laundry, errands) and leave the rest to my husband on the weekends. Right now I did develop one small liver met in March which has shrunk in size and so far is a solitary met which we are watching closely.  I don't mind if it stays there as long as it behaves and is an only child.  I hope for NED status, but I'm happy with "stable" right now and so is my oncologist.  In the meantime, I just keep holding on and praying that one day we really will get a cure. Prayers said for your sister that she has a positive response with few side effects, Cathy
Posts.Title: Kadcyla Experience Please goldengirl12 goldengirl12

I know there are some threads here that use that name and you will probably get more responses under that name. Good luck.

Posts.Content: Nov 26, 2012 05:25AM swimmom3 wrote: Naturegirl I can totally relate. I was given the results of my bone biopsy not even a week ago. 2 mets to my spine. I'm still in shock and will sit down with my doctor this week to figure out my treatment going forward. I wish I had advice to give you but since I'm new to stage IV I'm not much practical help. I just wanted to reach out and say you're not alone and send you hugs and prayers. Cathy
Posts.Title: Had CAT scan with contrast yesterday, waiting for results, help naturegirl2 DC197

Posts.Content: Nov 7, 2012 02:17PM swimmom3 wrote: Hello ladies.  I don't even know where to begin with questions, but I know I need support right now and I don't where to turn.  Today I had a CT scan and Bone scan as requirements for my participation in a clinical trial for denosumab.  I had a big scare last year with a Pet scan during my staging process which lit up in my T4/T5, my left shoulder, and my right hip and my left (good) breast.  Further testing with a bone/CT scan showed arthritis in my neck, and nothing in shoulder or hip.  Osteoarthritis and rheumatoid are very common in my family so it made sense.  My breast surgeon did an excisional biopsy on my left breast which revealed no cancer--just perfectly normal breast tissue.  Today as I lay on the table having my bone scan I could see a "bright white spot" in the middle of my back on the computer screen.  I had been having very vague back pain, but now there it was staring at me--a hot spot--I knew this was bad.  The technician took additional "films" while I was on the table and was very serious--another bad sign since she had been pretty casual before this.  Now fast forward to tonight and I pulled up my CT and bone scan results from the online charting system and both scans show activity at the T6 and the CT scan mentions the L1 and multiple tiny nodules on my liver which appear to be stable.  The T6 is described as a lytic lesion.  The lesions in my neck and hip and shoulder were compared to last year and continue to be described as osteoarthritis.  I've already emailed the study nurse so she can set up an appointment for me tomorrow with the doctor because I can't wait until Friday afternoon. I know I have to try and hold it together for my family, but I'm terrified that I am not going to be here to see my 3 sons become men with families of their own.  My oldest sons are 20 and 18, but my youngest is only 12, with some special needs to boot, and the thought of not being able to help him navigate to adulthood breaks my heart.  My husband is a good man and I know he would do his best, but it's still not the same. Please someone tell me--how do I hold onto hope??  Is it possible that the lytic lesion is not a bone met?  If it is confirmed as a bone met, what should I expect treatment wise?  Any advice or support would be a gift right now.
Posts.Title: If you are not Stage IV but have questions, you may post here chrissyb Olma61

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2012 04:46PM swimmom3 wrote: Well ladies, bone biopsy scheduled for Nov 15th.  Now I just have to wait.  Can anyone let me know how they felt after the biopsy so I can know how much help I might need that day and the next?  Also, how quickly should I expect results? Thank you again, especially to Ann and Moiralf for reaching out when I needed a shoulder to cry on.
Posts.Title: If you are not Stage IV but have questions, you may post here chrissyb Olma61

Posts.Content: Nov 9, 2012 05:28PM swimmom3 wrote: Thanks for your information about a bone biopsy.  I'm nervous to say the least, but my doctor said I would receive twilight sedation and shouldn't remember much.  Then he told me I would need to "take it easy" for about 24 hours or so.  Glad I'll have a few days to heal before Thanksgiving.  I hate that this will be hanging over our heads, but I don't want this to spoil the time with my family no matter what the result. Many thanks to all for your kind words and support.
Posts.Title: If you are not Stage IV but have questions, you may post here chrissyb Olma61

Posts.Content: Dec 26, 2012 05:08PM swimmom3 wrote: Skream--thank you for starting this thought provoking discussion.  I am learning so much by reading everyone's responses to this very important topic.  Limey, thank you for sharing your daughter's journey and giving me a good dose of hope.  I'm only a month into this stage iv stuff and I know that I need to believe that this can be a chronic condition (words that my MO used as well) that will allow me some quality of life while I continue to raise my children.  I'm not naive--I watched my best friend die of BC 14 years ago at the age of 35.  I guess I'm hoping that medical science will continue to develop new treatments and that my dear friend will be an angel on my shoulder guiding me through the worst of this.  Hope is a very powerful drug and it will definitely be part of my treatment plan (along with all that science can offer).  Wishing your daughter many many more years of living well despite a stage iv diagnosis.
Posts.Title: What do you make of the miracle stories? Skream DivineMrsM

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2012 03:15AM swimmom3 wrote: Thank you Moiralf for your kinds words.  You and Ann are amazing to reach out to me and i appreciate your words of wisdom as I try and navigate what is going on. I was able to see my MO this morning.  He squeezed me in on top of an already full schedule and that is why I love him--nothing comes before his patients.  He agreed that the CT and bone scan are very concerning for mets at T6 and L1 (L1 only showed up on CT, not bone scan).  Having said that, he said he would not jump the gun until I have a bone biopsy on both of those areas.  He remarked that my PET scan last year lit up in lots of places and it was all due to inflamation/arthritis.  This year's CT/bone scan confirm no changes to those areas--still arthritis.  He admits that some people just are more sensitive to scans than others and he feels I might fall into that category.  He is also looking beyond arthritis to other bone conditions that could cause these results (mentioned Paget's Disease).  Ultimately though the biopsy will confirm one way or the other and will also show the receptors which are important for possible additional treatment planning.  The liver nodules were just that--very tiny cysts that evidently were there last year on the CT, but are considered benign.  He said that the fact they have not changed in a year confirms that fact.  Who knew we have all these things going on in our bodies without knowing anything. We went to the worst case scenario--that this is bone mets--and he's already looking ahead to how it would be treated and what he would recommend.  First and foremost he would send me to Johns Hopkins to get a second opinion and and to be screened for clinical trials that they are running.  He is on the faculty at their medical school and is personal friends with their clincal trial breast cancer expert.  He also discussed the new treatment options for HER2 positive breast cancer including T-DM1 and Perjerta (sp??), and other drugs that for the moment escape my memory.  He basically said that IF this is cancer in my bones, he has lots of treatments available to keep me around for a long time. It was hard not to cry in front of him and with my poor husband fighting back tears next to me.  I'm going to try and take your good advice and stay focused on the present and wait for the biopsies to be scheduled. I want you to know that your kind words and wisdom have been such a blessing to me and please know that I hold you all in my hearts as well.  I have been following these boards since I was first diagnosed in 2011 but I have been too shy to participate in the discussions.  Time to let go of shy and jump right in the pool.  As the mother of 3 competitive swimmers, I hope I can make them proud.
Posts.Title: If you are not Stage IV but have questions, you may post here chrissyb Olma61

Posts.Content: Nov 7, 2012 02:50PM swimmom3 wrote: Bless you Ann for your quick response.  Everything that you wrote is what my brain knows is true.  I am not a doctor and I shouldn't even have looked at the scan but it's hard not to go to dark places when you see the concern on the technician's face. I will take your excellent advice and get some rest tonight and put this problem in God's hands while I try to sleep.  And you're so right--I don't want to waste a moment on worry since I'll never get that moment back--cancer or no cancer. Sending you cyberhugs and much thanks for talking me off a ledge--I'm still standing on the ledge, but I'm going to look around and enjoy the beautiful sky before I jump.
Posts.Title: If you are not Stage IV but have questions, you may post here chrissyb Olma61

Posts.Content: swimmom3 wrote: I know as stage iv, we have to be prepared that anything goes, but I've had a really bad stretch of events/side effects and I hope you can help. On Christmas night, after feeling some pain in my right hip for about a week (X-Ray was negative for fracture) I suffered a sudden pathological fracture there. Nothing says Christmas like a ride in an ambulance screaming in pain. I spent a lost week in the hospital where I was so drugged up after surgery that I have very little memory of it, then another week learning to get mobile with a walker before being shipped off to rehab for almost another 2 weeks. I came home the end of January and began in home PT which was successful and today I get around my house without my cane and just use it when I go out. In the midst of recovery, treatment with herceptin, perjeta, letrozole, lupron shots and zometa continued and I also did 10 rad sessions to my pelvis. Tomorrow I see my oncologist and I feel like human wreckage. Every bone in my body hurts, I have terrible hot flashes, insomnia, gastro issues, neuropathy in feet and hands, and bed hugging levels of fatigue. I'm guessing a lot of these symptoms are related to the letrozole, and they are getting worse over time (been on it for over 1.5 years). Scans in the hospital showed mostly stable disease so not sure if progression is rearing its ugly head. New symptom includes weak pincer grasp in right hand which scares me since it seems like a neurological symptom. My question is do you ladies have advice on how to isolate what is causing the majority of these symptoms and what do you do to motivate yourself to push through when you feel so crappy. Prior to breaking my hip, treatment made me tired but it was more manageable. I feel like this event has worn me down and I hope I can bounce back. Grateful for any advice you can give. Dx 8/2011, IDC, 2cm, Stage IIIA, Grade 3, 4/18 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2+ Targeted Therapy 9/6/2011 Herceptin (trastuzumab) Chemotherapy 9/6/2011 Carboplatin (Paraplatin), Taxotere (docetaxel) Surgery 1/25/2012 Lymph node removal: Right, Underarm/Axillary; Mastectomy: Right; Prophylactic mastectomy: Left Radiation Therapy 2/27/2012 Breast, Lymph nodes Dx 11/19/2012, IDC, Stage IV, mets Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Trying to get past several bad months swimmom3 artistatheart

Posts.Content: Jan 9, 2013 08:11AM swimmom3 wrote: I had a ct guided biopsy which did confirm the mets, but the radiologist did say that sometimes they don't get a good sample. It's rare if its guided but at least in my case because the lesion was in a tricky spot it was possible. I hope your mom gets some answers soon.
Posts.Title: Can A Bone Biopsy Miss Something? GoldenGirls GoldenGirls

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2013 09:27PM swimmom3 wrote: Renae please don't waste precious time worrying about "why?".  Use your time wisely to learn as much about your diagnosis and possible treatments and more importantly to cherish and enjoy all the good people and things in your life.  I'm new to this diagnosis too, but the only thing I understand is I have today and today is good and I'm going to enjoy every moment.  When the dark thoughts or "why did this happen" creep in I find I'm missing out on what's before me that moment--which is usually my husband or children--and I don't want to miss a moment of their company.  Wishing you a long life to enjoy those good people and things in your life too.  Hugs, Cathy
Posts.Title: Why, why, why....?! Renae64

Posts.Content: Dec 22, 2012 12:34PM swimmom3 wrote: Sherri. Thank you for your wonderful gift of hope. I'm only about a month into this stage IV diagnosis and I will have to break the news to our youngest after Christmas. He's 12 and I want to be able to reassure him that his mom will still be here for a long time to come. I will tell him your wonderful story so he knows moms not going anywhere anytime soon. Merry Christmas to you and happy birthday to your darling boy. -Cathy
